725840f-a.title: Queens: West Drive - Alston Place
725840f-a.text:
The old Dutch colonial house at the corner of West Drive and Alston Pl.
in Douglas Manor, Douglaston, New York, now owned by Mr. and Mrs. L. Kelville
Larson was built in 1735 by Cornelius Van Wyck. He was the eldest son of
Johannes Van Wyck whose father, an earlier Cornelius Van Wyck, was one of the
patentees of Mid-Wout, having emigrated there from Holland in 166O.
In 1705, 125 acres of larnd south and east of the present house at West
Drive and Alston Pl., was purchased from Richard and Sarah Cornell by Johannes
Van Wyck. His brother Theodorus had already accuired land on Eing's Point.
Johannes had three sons and Tour daughters and became a Justice of the Provin-
cial Courts.
When Justice Johannes died in 1734, the property was inherited by his
eldest son Cornelius who had married Mary Hicks, daughter of Judge Isaac Hicks.
Cornelius and Mary prospered, added to the original farm, and until Cornelius'
death in 1759, lived in the house they had built twenty-four years earlier.
Cornelius left three sons - Stephan, Cornelius II, and Gilbert. Stephan,
the eldest, inherited the house and flourishing farm. Cornelius II had the
misfortune of being captured by the British in a surprise raid on Flushing and
was confined aboard one of the notorious prison ships anchored in the Wallabout
(Bay). He died soon after his release from the effects of a year's confine-
oeut upder horrible conditions. Stephan fell heir to the appointment as
E1P:E.W.T2.YTC:5T5Ei,35R1''R9,3~eR ~3R 22R-e~E~8R
Gilbert Van Wyck, the youngest of the three brothers, was a Tory and
served as a justice of the peace for King George III until the end of the war
when he joined the Tory exodus to Nova Scotia. His cousins Captain Thomas
Hicks and Captain Thomas Van Wyck, who had remained loyal to the crown, went
with him.
However, M. jor Cornelius Vin Wyck, Gilbert's son, fought with the Con-
tinental army for the duration of the war since he did not share his father's
political views.
. in 1789, Major Cornelius Van Wyck inherited the house and  Conseguently.
land jointly with'his cousin Steghan, son of the Cornelius-of-the-prison-ship.
Stephan was not interested in farming and sold his interest to Major Cornelius
who thus became the last Van Wyck owner of the house his grandfather built in
1735. The major held the property for another thirty yeabs and in 1819 sold
it to Wynant Van 2andt, one of the early merchants and an alderman of old New
York City.
Van 2andt, who had previously purchased the adjoining 12O acres to the
north now commonly known aa ''the point'' area of Douglas Manor, began in 1819
the construction of a large manor house in ''Tha Point'' section. It is assumed
that his family occupied the Van Wyck house during the construction of the new
manor house. IIn fact, among several interesting items found in the chimney
place of the old house during some restoration work were two copy books
signed by Charlotte Van 2andt, presumably one of Van 2andt's four daughters.
In addition they had eleven sons so could well use the large new manor house.
In 1835 George Douglas purchased the Manor house and the 12O acres on
the point. After his death in 1862 his son William inherited the property.
During the tenure of the Douglas family the old Van Wyck house was used as a
guest house or was rented to friends. One such was Dr. Edward Livingston
Trudeau, who founded the famous tuberculosis sanitarium at Saranac Lake, New
York. Trudeau married in 1871 Charlotte Beare whose father was rector of
2ion Episcopal Church in Douglaston for 45'Sears, from 264E to 1847. The IE 37eAi
Beare family were close friends of the Douglas' and when Truieau and Charlotte
Beare were married, William Douglas gave the wedding reception in the Manor
House. After a honeymoon of several months in Europe, the couple rented the
old Van Wyck house and lived there for the first year of their married life.
In 1906 the entire property, including the Manor House and the old Van
Wyck house, was sold to the Douglas Manor Company. The Manor House became
an inn and the old Van Wyck house became the first home of the Douglaston
Club. In 1921 the Douglaston Club took posession of the Manor House and it
is still being used as the community social and recreational center. The old
Van Wyck house was bought by Mr. and Wrs. E.M. Wicht who did away with
some structures which had been added when the house was used as a club and
restored the old house to its original foundation. In 1933 the house was
purchased by Mr. and Mrs. L. Keville Larson who are still in residence.
June 1965
C. Manley Ue Bevoise
5105 Browvale Lane
Little Neck, N.Y.
